- More technically, there has to be Shannon mutual information between the evidential event and the target of inquiry, relative to your current state of uncertainty about both of them.

when you find inconsistencies in your opponents words and actions. Nobody likes to be a hypocrite find out what your counterparts usual behavior.

the concept of "birds of a feather flock together." You send subtle signals that you're similar to your counterpart and should be bonding with. Seen often body language. Vos' recommendation: Repeat the last three words of what the person just said

cards.note: Your mindset should be that of discovery. Learn as much about the situation as possible

When you control something your counterpart wishes to avoid

super high trait C. They prepare a lot and are very calculating but beware that you're not offputting by how cold you are. Hypersensitive to reciprocity. Highly introverted. Use data and reason with them. Not quick to answer calibrated questions
a type of tactical empathy; understanding your opponents emotions, articulating them, and respectfully verbalizing

cards.quote: Assumptions blind, hypotheses guide.

cards.note: Use your opponent's deadlines against them. Cars salesman are more likely to give good deals at end of the month, businessmen at end of the financial quarter.

cards.back: 7% of what we communicate is done so through the verbal word, 35% is through the tone and intonation, and 55% is through our body language.

time is money. Perfection not necessary. Winning is the goal. Prioritization of respect. Must be heard. Tell not ask. Every silence is an opportunity to speak more. If you're dealing with this type, mirrors and calibrated questions are both excellent options. Look for the that's right

cards.note: Avoid anchoring (giving the first offer) in monetary bargaining. But beware of sharks who will give a ludicrous anchor to throw you off.
Who has control in a negotiation the talker or the listener? The listener of course. That's because the talker is revealing information.
In general, *that's right* is what you're looking for. It signals your counterpart believes they've come up with the solution themselves. Alternatively, *you're right* is bad and often dismissive.
Voss asks the same open ended questions until they get frustrated and give up

cards.back: That negotiation is an exercise in tactical empathy and honing those skills can improve your life.
identifying all the reaso's you counterpart might be angry with you.

cards.front: The three voices you should use when negotiating:
cards.back:
The FM DJ voice: a self-assured voice of calm and reason, use it calm down your counterpart
A positive playful voice: Use most of the time, encourages positivity and cooperation
An assertive dominant voice: Use with caution
high trait A. Very friendly. Be friendly with them. They might leave out objections or problem areas to avoid conflict
Sudden surprising information which changes the balance of leverage in a negotiation
when you can provide something that your counterpart desires

cards.note: In a job interview or salary negotiation, ask "what does it take to be successful here." That'll give the boss a personal stake in your success. You've just created an unofficial mentor
Good negotiator know they need to be ready for surprises. Great negotiators use their skills to reveal the surprises they're certain exist.
The FBI developed their negotiation methods through iteration while having intense skin in the game.Harvard intellectuals did so through theory. Consequently, the FBI methods were superior.

cards.front: The effects of likelihood ratios on probability ratios
cards.back: When we see evidence, hypotheses that assigned a higher likelihood to that evidence gain probability, at the expense of hypotheses that assigned a lower likelihood to the evidence.

cards.quote: Deductive logic is the branch of logic that studies what follows with certainty. Inductive logic deals with uncertainty, things that only follow with high probability.

cards.back:
Box A is clear, and always contains a visible $1,000.
Box B is opaque, and its content has already been set by the predictor:
If the predictor has predicted the player will take both boxes A and B, then box B contains nothing.
If the predictor has predicted that the player will take only box B, then box B contains $1,000,000.

First Law
- A robot may not injure a human being or, through inaction, allow a human being to come to harm.
Second Law
- A robot must obey the orders given it by human beings except where such orders would conflict with the First Law.
Third Law
- A robot must protect its own existence as long as such protection does not conflict with the First or Second Law

cards.quote: Only a man exceedingly proud and vain would believe that his heir should be like himself, rather than like who he wished that he could be.

cards.back: a broad class of computational algorithms that rely on repeated random sampling to obtain numerical results. The underlying concept is to use randomness to solve problems that might be deterministic in principle.

Because nothing's black and white, there exist only equally grey things

Not a propositional assertion, so much as a cognitive traffic signal: do not think past this point.

- A cognitive bias in which you assume people will understand your attempts at communication (writing, speech, etc.) because you know what you're saying
- Related to hindsight bias

In our ancestral environment, you were unlikely to end up more than one inferential step away from anyone else. Anyone who says something with no obvious support is a liar or an idiot. Conversely, if you say something blatantly obvious and the other person doesn’t see it, they’re the idiot, or they’re being deliberately obstinate to annoy you.

- the I-knew-it-all-along phenomenon
- Subjects who know the actual answer to a question assign much higher probabilities they “would have” guessed for that answer, compared to subjects who must guess without knowing the answer.

- an embarrassing or tactless act or remark in a social situation.
- French, literally ‘false step’.

When evaluating other people, we tend to explain their behaviour as fundamental personality traits instead of consequences of their recent experiences (eg someone just yelled at them). This is because we don't see what they've been through before encountering them

cards.quote: Harry sent his parents a glare. "I am a conscientious objector to child conscription, on grounds that I should not have to suffer for a disintegrating school system's failure to provide teachers or study materials of even minimally adequate quality."

cards.back:
- a probabilistic technique for approximating the global optimum of a given function.
- Name comes from annealing in metallurgy, a technique involving heating and controlled cooling of a material to increase the size of its crystals and reduce their defects.
- Slow cooling = slow decrease in the probability of accepting worse solutions as the solution space is explored.
the probability of obtaining test results at least as extreme as the results actually observed, under the assumption that the null hypothesis is correct.
